Award.AwardTitle: A New Approach Toward Optimal and Adaptive Nonparametric Methods for High-Frequency Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
High frequency monitoring of complex systems, which operate in continuous time, is increasingly important in many fields such as neural science, turbulence, and environmental sciences. This tendency, however, has been particularly predominant in financial markets with the advent of transaction and Limit Order Book data sets, which constitute two prototypical examples of "big data" in statistics. In light of the just mentioned technological advances, statistical inference methods for continuous time processes based on high-frequency observations have seen a rapid evolution in the last few years. One of the crucial issues with the current state of art of the subject lies in the fact that most of the proposed methods critically depend on tuning parameters that need to be calibrated. This, of course, is the case with most of the nonparametric methods used in other classical statistical problems. However, the extensive literature for resolving these problems in other frameworks has not yet been fully translated into the context of high-frequency-based inference for stochastic processes. Another important issue comes from the common practice of adopting artificial models specified by stochastic dynamical systems, which are known to lack sufficient accuracy for describing the stylized features of asset prices at ultra high frequency. This, in turn, has motivated the introduction of the concept of microstructure noise, but sometimes, again, assuming unnatural assumptions. Hence, there is a real need for bottom-up derivations of models that allow a better understanding of the underlying asset price formation.

The principal investigator will tap on the previously mentioned needs and is expected to significantly advance the area in the following three primary directions of theoretical and practical relevance: (1) Devise new methodologies towards the implementation of "optimal" inference methods in regard to the intrinsic tuning parameters of the methods; (2) Develop a new approach, together with the necessary theoretical foundations, for adaptive estimation methods based on data-driven fixed point procedures; (3) Better incorporation of Limit Order Book data in the modeling of both the underlying approximating jump-diffusion process and the microstructure noise with a view of enhancing the estimation of latent process parameters based on limit order book information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out through this grant enabled use to get a much greater understanding of optimal statistical methods for dynamical stochastic systems that evolve continuously in time and that may exhbit abrupt changes in short time periods. 

One of the main goals of the research was to develop efficient and optimal methods to detect these abrupt changes. In other words, we aim to answer how large the change in the observed state variable of interest must be in order for the time interval where this change ocurred to be judged as atypical. The proposed methods are completely data-driven and, as mentioned before, approximately optimal which results in better performance in finite sample settings. 

The funded research resulted in 8 publications as listed below:

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez and C. Li (2020). Optimal Kernel Estimation of Spot Volatility of Stochastic Differential Equations. Accepted In Stochastic Processes and their Applications. DOI: doi.org/10.1016/j.spa.2020.01.013

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez and C. Mancini (2019). Optimum thresholding using mean and conditional mean square error. The Journal of Econometrics. 208 (1). DOI: 10.1016/j.jeconom.2018.09.011.

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez and J. Nisen (2019). Second-order properties of thresholded realized power variations of FJA additive processes. Statistical Inference for Stochastic Processes. 22 (3). DOI: 10.1007/s11203-019-09198-w.

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez and S. Olafsson (2019). Change-point detection for Levy processes. Annals of Applied Probability. 29 (2). DOI: 10.1214/17-AAP1368.

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez and Y. Luo (2018). Small-time expansions for state-dependent local jump-diffusion models with infinite jump activity. Stochastic Processes and their Applications. 128 (12). DOI: 10.1016/j.spa.2018.02.001.

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez, C. Li, and J. Nisen (2020). Optimal Iterative Threshold-Kernel Estimation of Jump Diffusion Processes. Submitted In Statistical Inference for Stochastic Processes.

J.E. Figueroa-Lopez, H. Lee, and R. Pasupathy (2018). Optimal placement of a small order in a diffusive limit order book. High Frequency. 1 (2), 87. DOI: 10.1002/hf2.10017.

Q. Wang, J.E. Figueroa-Lopez, and T. Kuffner (2020). Bayesian Inference on Volatility in the Presence of Infinite Jump Activity and Microstructure Noise. Submitted In Electronic Journal Of Statistics.

The project also allowed the PI to direct the research of 5 Ph.D. students and provide research opportunities for 10 master students and 3 undergraduate students. During this period, the PI graduated one Ph.D. student who is pursuing an academic position. 

The most important findings are listed below:

(1) Thershold estimators aim to identify atpical increments (aja jumps) by comparing them to a threshod parameters. We study the optimal way to select such a tunning parameter and found a parsimonious characterization of this optimal threshold. In the case of constant variability through time and finitely many jumps, the optimal threshold is shown to be asymptotically equivalent, in a high-frequency regime, to the modulus of continuity of the Brownian component of the model and the volatility of the process. This interdependence between the optimal estimator and the parameter that this is supposed to estimate allow us to devise a novel implementation algorithm where the threshold and volatility are iteratively updated. Based on Monte Carlo simulations, the resulting data-driven estimator outperforms any other estimator found in the literature. The PI has been able to extend the result to a general (time-varying) volatility process that is bounded and continuous on the specified time interval of estimation. Other more complex type of processes are considered.

(2) By assuming that the covariance function of the variance process of a Dynamical Stochastic System satisfies a local scaling property, optimal tunnig parameters of a class of nonparametric methods for the estimation of the local variability of the system were explicitly characterized in closed form. The optimal bandwidth depends on a path roughness index.

(3) Also, we consider the problem of finding the optimal kernel function of the estimator (assuming that the bandwidth has already been selected optimally). It is proved that the exponential kernel is optimal for Brownian-driven volatilities, which is new finding for a class of models used in many applications. 

(4) Recently, some of our results described above have been extended to incorporate leverage effects when a correlated Brownian motion drives the volatility process and Microstructure noise.
